Event: Commander James Cook claims theeast coast of Australia for Britain in his first voyage to the Pacific
On his third and ill fated last voyage to the Pacific, Captain James Cook makes landfall in Tasmania at Adventure Bay, Bruny Island

The Colony of New South Wales declared by the Kingdom of Great Britain 25th April 1787, east of 135° east and all islands adjacent in the Pacific Ocean between the latitudes of 10°37' south and 43°39' south, including most of New Zealand
The First Fleet arrives, landing at Sydney Cove 26th Jan 1788 bearing 543 convict men and 189 convict women
Governor Arthur Phillip proclaimed the establishment of the Colony of New South Wales; 7th Feb 1788
Smallpox outbreak hits the local Aboriginal population particularly hard, killing at least half of the Aboriginal population around the Sydney settlement
Aboriginal warrior of the Eora nation, Pemulwuy leads the resistance against the Sydney colonists, Governor Phillip is speared but recovers and continues as governor.
Establishment of the whaling industry in Sydney
Governor Phillip returns to England with two Aboriginal men, Bennelong and Yemmerrawannie. Only Bennelong returns to Australia.
The departure of Governor Phillip to England marked the beginning of the Rum Corps, with Major Francis Grose becoming the Lieutenant-Governor
Hawkesbury River massacre, first acknowledged massacre of Aboriginal people by white colonists
Introduction of merino sheep
James Squire's The Malting Shovel tavern is licensed, being the first commercial brewer of hopped beer in Australia
Matthew Flinders and George Bass circumnavigate Van Diemen's Land proving it to be an island
Matthew Flinders circumnavigates the continent that he calls 'Australia'
The first British settlement in what would later become Victoria was established at Sullivan Bay (Sorrento), which was abandoned the following year
First European settlement of Van Diemen's Land at Risdon Cove
Castle Hill convict uprising
Governor Bligh (of mutiny of the Bounty fame) arrives in Sydney as the next governor and immediately attempts to crack down on the Marine Corps' use of rum for payment among other unpopular actions

The Rum Rebellion, military command of the colony with Governor Bligh being arrested by the Marine Corps (1808) to when John MacArthur and Major George Johnston are arrested and sent to England for trial and the Marine Corps are recalled (1810)
Isaac Nichols appointed Australia's first postmaster
Governor Lachlan Macquarie arrives
Macquarie Island discovered by Frederick Hasselborough who claimed it for the United Kingdom and declared it part of New South Wales
Absalom West, an emancipated convict, sets up a business as publisher of prints in Sydney, publishing engravings of the early colony
John Lewin sets up the first art school in Sydney.
Blaxland, Lawson, and Wentworth cross the Blue Mountains
Introduction of Australia's first coin, the holey dollar, replacing rum as currency
Road across the Blue Mountains completed and the town of Bathurst is established, first inland European settlement
Rum hospital opens, the first public hospital in Australia
Bank of New South Wales established
The first successful introduction of European honey bees
John Thomas Bigge's 'The State of the Colony of New South Wales' is published, leading to harsher treatment of convicts
The first Clydesdale horses arrive in Van Diemen's Land
First print of the Hobart Town Gazette, first free press publication in Australia
Founding of Brisbane, Moreton Bay Penal Settlement
New South Wales extended west to 129° east, including Melville Island, and adjacent islands latitude moved north to 39°12' south, only encompassing a small section of New Zealand
The southern islands of New South Wales made the Colony of Van Diemen's Land
Pineapples are introduced to Australia
Founding of the Swan River Colony
Mak Sai Ying (aka John Shying) became the first documented Chinese landholder in NSW, and became the first Chinese publican, being granted the license for the Golden Lion Inn in Parramatta
Van Diemen's Land introduces a 'Protector' of Aborigines, followed by other colonies in subsequent years
Van Diemen's Land - The 'Black Line', colonist's attempts to force Aboriginal people out of colonised areas
Australia's first novelist, Henry Savery, publishes Quintus Servinton
James Stirling appointed governor of the Colony of Western Australia, marking the change of name from Swan River Colony
Introduction of assisted migration for British settlers
Mechanics School of Arts opened in Sydney to promote cultural development and learning
Convict transportation peaks with nearly 7,000 convicts arriving in one year
Convict ship Neva wrecked off King Island with the loss of 224 lives
John Batman "negotiates" the purchase of land from the local Wurundjeri elders (covering the future location of Melbourne), which was then annulled by the Governer of New South Wales
The Province of South Australia created 19th Feb 1836, proclamation occurred on 28th Dec 1836
Richard Bourke, the Governor of New South Wales, declares the Yarra River settlement as the administrative capital of the Port Phillip District of New South Wales
Hobart holds the first art exhibition
Briefly named Batmania, Governor Bourke names the Yarra River settlement Melbourne
Myall Creek massacre, one of the few massacres of Aboriginal people proven in court and the only one to result in the conviction and execution of any of the perpetrators
The first 'Protection Board' for managing the Indigenous population is established in Port Phillip District (Victoria), followed by similar controlling structures in other colonies.
The islands of New Zealand annexed to New South Wales 15th Jun 1839, proclaimed 14th Jan 1840
First volume of John Gould's Birds of Australia published, with Elizabeth Gould a major contributor to the work
The Treaty of Waitangi signed 6th Feb 1840
The Colony of New Zealand is chartered and to be split from New South Wales
Captain Augustin Lucas is credited with taking the first daguerreotype photograph in Australia of Bridge Street, Sydney
New Zealand separates from New South Wales to become an independent colony
George Goodman starts the first commercial photography venture in Sydney, taking photographic daguerrotype portraits for one guinea each.
John Wrathall Bull invents and John Ridley manufactures in South Australia the worlds first mechanised grain stripper.
First elections for the Legislative Council in New South Wales are held
Norfolk Island transferred from New South Wales to Van Diemen's Land
Cataraqui wrecks off King Island with 400 dead in Australia's deadliest maritime civil disaster
The north half of New South Wales north of 26° south made the Colony of North Australia
Douglas Kilburn makes daguerreotypes of Kulin people, which are engraved and published in England in 1850
Queen Victoria revoked the letters patent esablishing North Australia 28th Dec 1847, proclaimed in Australia 16th Jan 1849
The Australlasian Anti-Transportation League, the first popular national movement is established
Ludwig Leichhardt's third expedition vanishes
Establishment of the Native Police
Convict transportation from Britain to Port Phillip district ceases
Convict transportation from Britain to New South Wales ceases
Founding of Sydney University
Black Thursday bushfires devastate the colony of Port Phillip District (Victoria)
Colony of Victoria established
Gold is struck in Bathurst, New South Wales and Ballarat, Victoria, marking the start of the Gold Rush era
The Illustrated Sydney News becomes Australia's first illustrated newspaper
Gundagai floods - 89 die in Australia's deadliest flood
Paddle steamers begin plying the Murray river
Convict transportation from Britain to Van Diemen's Land ceases
Australia's first steam railway line opens, running from Melbourne to Sandridge (Port Melbourne)
Eureka Stockade
The Chinese population in Australia reaches 50,000
The European red fox introduced into Australia for recreational hunting
Van Diemen's Land renamed Tasmania
James Harrison produces the worlds first ice making machine and refrigerator
Secret ballot voting introduced into Australia, first in Tasmania, then Victoria and South Australia, the method pioneered by William Nicholson of Melbourne becomes known as the 'Australian Ballot'

Introduction of male suffrage and secret ballot in South Australia (1856), followed by Victoria (1857), New South Wales (1858), and Tasmania (1900). Britain retains control over foreign affairs and defence.
Melbourne building workers win an eight hour day
Norfolk Island is split from Tasmania, becoming its own colony
First balloon flight in Australia, Richmond Victoria
First organised game of Australian Rules football, likely based on forms of similar Indigenous Australian games
Colony of Queensland established
Introduction of rabbits into Australia
Australia's first stock exchange opens in Melbourne
John Walter Osborne develops the process of Photolithography in order to record surveyor's maps using glass slides
Burke and Wills expedition, which included the first camels imported into Australia
Land Act legislation in Victoria opens up land to settlers, followed by New South Wales the following year
National Gallery of Victoria established
Anti-Chinese riots at Lambing Flat goldfields, driving over 1,000 Chinese miners off the goldfields
Portion of New South Wales west of South Australia transferred to South Australia
First Melbourne Cup horse race
South Australian propertied women are granted the right to vote in local elections, followed by parliamentary elections in 1894
First viable sugar cane plantation
Portion of New South Wales north of South Australia and east of 138° east transferred to Queensland
First South Sea Islanders brought to Queensland as indentured labour, the start of 'blackbirding'
Coranderrk Aboriginal Reserve established
The first Rugby Union club formed at Sydney University
The region of New South Wales north of South Australia transferred to South Australia
Trout introduced to Australia
National Gallery School of Art of Victoria established
Australia's first royal visit by Prince Alfred, son of Queen Victoria
Measles outbreak in Sydney, most of the victims are under the age of 4
Convict transportation to Australia ends, with convict transportation to Western Australia ceasing
Aboriginal cricket team tours England
Granny Smith Apple cultivar propogated by Maria Ann Smith in New South Wales
Joseph Keen from Tasmania wins a medal for his Keen's Curry Powder (not related to the English Keen's Mustard, with both products acquired by McCormick's Foods in 1998)
Newspaper columnist, Marcus Clarke writes about the coffee stalls in Melbourne which date to at least the 1850s
An Act for the 'Protection and Management of Aboriginal Natives' is passed in the parliament of Victoria
The first Aboriginal children are enrolled in public schools in New South Wales
Australian Natives' Association formed
The New South Wales Academy of Art is founded. From 1883, it was known as the National Art Gallery of New South Wales, then from 1958 the Art Gallery of New South Wales (AGNSW)
The first Amateur Photographic Society of New South Wales is formed
The New South Wales police begin using photography to take mug shots of suspects and criminals
Queensland annexes all islands within 60 miles (97 km) of its coast to incorporate the Torres Strait Islands.
Completion of the Overland Telegraph from Darwin to Port Augusta, South Australia
Free, compulsory and secular education introduced in Victoria
Louis Brennan invents the underwater torpedo
Scarlet Fever epidemic, killing 8,000+
Richard and Clarence Bowyer Smith invent the stump-jump plough allowing plowing of fields with stumps and stones
The Victoria Football Association (VFA) is established
Frederick York Wolseley invents the first practical mechanical wool shearing clippers

Phylloxera first detected in Geelong before spreading to other states. While many vineyards converted to resistent American rootstocks many Australian vineyards are still on European rootstocks, especially in South Australia
Loch Ard sinks off the Shipwreck Coast, Victoria with the loss of 53 people
Banana plantations started in Queensland
First Greek fish and chip shop opened in Sydney
Australia's first national park created in Sydney
All Torres Strait Islands are annexed by Queensland
The Bulletin established
Macquarie Island transferred to the Colony of Tasmania
Ned Kelly hanged after the shootout and capture at Glenrowan
Smallpox epidemic in southern States from 1881 to 1885
Queensland claims southeast New Guinea as a dependency, which is rejected by the British Government
Henrietta Dugdale forms the first Australian women's suffrage society in Melbourne
First regional art gallery in Australia opens in Ballarat
The British Empire declares southeast New Guinea as a protectorate, removing it from Queensland control, although Queensland still administers it
BHP begins mining at Broken Hill
Victorian Employers' Union formed, forerunner of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry
Beginnings of the Heidelberg school (an art movement of Australian Impressionism), most being students of the National Gallery School of Art in Melbourne
The Chaffey brothers introduce irrigation from the Murray river
RMIT University in Melbourne introduces the first photography course as an inaugural discipline. It is the oldest ongoing photography course in the world
Start of the pearling industry in Broome
Melbourne Centenial Exhibition
Australian Art published, the first Australian magazine devoted to art
Black stem rust epidemic causes significant loss in wheat production, requiring importing of wheat
Arthur James Arnot patents the first electric drill
9 by 5 Impressionist exhibition in Melbourne
Henry Parkes' Tenterfield Oration calling for federation
Flu pandemic
Julian Ashton School of Arts / Sydney Art School opens in Sydney
Economic Depression - 1890 - 1893
Maritime and Shearers' strikes
Creation of the Australian Labor Party
Typhoid epidemic in Western Australia between 1891 - 1910, killing over 2,000
Arthur Patrick McCormick invents the Coolgardie safe for preserving and keeping food cool

Lawrence Hargrave's first heavier than air box kite flight, the designs of which were to later make it into the American Wright Brothers Wright Flyer to achieve the first powered flight with a pilot on board in 1903.
Woman's suffrage introduced in South Australia, first electorate in the world
Federation Drought; 1895 - 1903, the worst since the start of European settlement
Heat wave in south-eastern Australia kills 427 people
Edwin Flack becomes Australia's first Olympian
One-guinea Pocket Kodak cameras are introduced into Australia. Over 3,000 are sold within two months
The inaugural seaon of the Victorian Football League (VFL), having formed out of the VFA
Crown Studios in Sydney introduces colour photography using the three-exposure Joly and Ives process
Three-minute automatic photo booths are established in Sydney
Australia's deadliest cyclone Mahina at Bathurst Bay, Queensland with over 410 deaths
Bubonic plague arrives in Australia
The Kodak Brownie, the first mass-marketed camera, is released
Neville Howse becomes the first Australian to receive a Victoria Cross while serving with the NSW Army Medical Corps in the Second South African (Boer) War
Inauguration of the Commonwealth of Australia
Miles Franklin publishes 'My Brilliant Career'
White Australia policy enshrined in law
J.A. Birchall from Launceston invents the notepad, multiple sheets backed by cardboard and glued together at the top
Harry 'Breaker' Morant executed
Mount Kembla mining disaster results in the deaths of 96 miners
Women of European descent given the vote in federal elections
William Farrer's black stem rust and drought resistent 'Federation' wheat released
Charles Potter and Guillaume Delprat develop the froth flotation process for separating minerals from rocks
Picture postcards combining photography, printing, and postage become popular
Australia takes control of British New Guinea as an 'external territory', becoming the Territory of Papua
World's first feature-length film 'The Story of the Kelly Gang' produced in Victoria
The first surf life-saving reel demonstrated at Bondi Beach by its designer, Lester Ormsby
Australia's first lifesaving club established at Bondi
Justice HB Higgins hands down 'Harvester Judgement' setting the first minimum wage ruling
Rugby league splits from rugby union
George Mitchell invents the thrust block bearing, initially used on ship propellers, now used on turbine shafts and power plants worldwide.
Heat wave in southern states kills 246 people
The inaugural Wynne Prize is awarded to Walter Withers for The Storm
Melbourne company Baker and Rouse merges with Kodak to form Australia Kodak Limited, with a manufacturing plant created in Abbotsford, New South Wales
Sunshine rail disaster, train runs into the back of another train, killing 44
Legislation introduced for national age and invalid pensions
The Quarantine Act is passed, providing a national approach to the prevention and eradication of imported plant, animal, and human diseases
The first season of Rugby League is played in Australia
First flight of heavier-than-air glider by George Taylor in Narrabeen, New South Wales, Australia
First powered flight of heavier-than-air machine by Colin Defries in Sydney, Australia
Walter Hume develops the Humespun pipe-making process for making concrete pipes using centrifugal force, revolutionising pipe manufacturing
John Dethridge invents the Dethridge wheel to measure the water flow in irrigation channels
First flight of an Australian built plane
Drought of 1911 - 1916
The Federal Capital Territory split from New South Wales and the Northern Territory split from South Australia
Temperance campaigners succeeded in a prohibition on the sale of alcohol in the new Federal Capital Territory. This remains in place until Parliament moves from Melbourne to Canberra
Douglas Mawson's expedition to Antarctica, with Frank Hurley appointed its official photographer
The Commonwealth Football Association is established, the first governing body for football (soccer) in Australia
Builders Labourers' Federation (BLF) established, one of Australia's oldest federated unions
Harry and Jack McLaren invent the surf ski
South Australian Lance de Mole submits a design for a military tank to the British War Office. He was later recognised by the British with an award as the inventor of the Mark I tank
16 year old Cliff Howard invents the self-propelled rotary hoe
Maternity allowance introduced for woman of European descent
Foundation of Canberra as the national capital
Royal Australian Navy receives seven new warships in agreement with Britain
Sir George Julius makes the first automatic totalisator for calculating horse-racing bets
Norfolk Island transferred from the United Kingdom, becoming the Territory of Norfolk Island
Prime Minister Joseph Cook pledges full support of Britain following Britain going to war against Germany, marking the start of Australia's involvement in World War I
The first pilots of the Australian Flying Corp are trained at Point Cook, Melbourne. The Point Cook aerodrome is the oldest continuously operating military aerodrome in the world
New South Wales government gains power to remove Aboriginal children from their families, in a law that was soon emulated by other States
25th April, Australian and New Zealander troops land at what is now called Anzac Cove, Gallipoli
Lance-Corporal W C Beech invents the periscope rifle while serving at Gallipoli

Following a campaign from the temperance movement, a SA referendum in 1915, and referendums in NSW and Tas, and Vic just passing a law in 1916, public houses had to close by 6pm coining the term 'six o'clock swill'
A small peninsula along Jervis Bay is ceded to the Federal Capital Territory by New South Wales
Founding of the Advisory Council of Science and Industry which would later become the CSIRO

Founding of the Sydney Camera Circle, heavily influenced by and influencing the Pictoralist approach to photography, emphasising sunlight rather than the shadows common of the overseas Pictoralist movement
Conscription for overseas military service defeated in two referendums
First Anzac Day commemorations
The Clements Brothers invent Gravox
Frank Hurley is appointed Australia's first official war photographer for the Australian Imperial Force
Francis McNamara is awarded the Victoria Cross while serving in the Australian Flying Corp near Gaza for rescuing a fellow downed pilot
Federal-state soldier settler program
Chemist George Nicholas invents Aspro, a form of aspirin in a tablet
Completion of the Trans-Australian railway connecting Port Augusta and Kalgoorlie
11th of November, the Armistice ending the First World War came into effect
The Darwin beer rebellion which resulted in the Northern Territory being granted a seat in the House of Representatives
Influenza pandemic reaches Australia
Building on the perishable anthrax vaccine discovered by Louis Pasteur, John McGarvie creates a non-perishable anthrax vaccine
Treaty of Versailles signed following the end of the First World War
First flight crossing the Australian continent from Melbourne to Darwin by Henry Wrigley and Arthur Murphy

The Australian government posted an award for the first plane to fly from Britain to Australia. Ross Smith and his brother Keith Smith along with mechanics James Bennett and Wally Shiers claimed the prize
First flight across Bass Straight from Tasmania to Victoria by Arthur Long
Financial inflation/recession from 1919 - 1923
Anthony Mitchell invents the crankless engine, removing the need for a crankshaft to start an engine
Anzac Biscuit recipe first published
Country Party founded at national level
Qantas established
League of Nations mandates the former German New Guinea to Australia as the Territory of New Guinea
League of Nations assigns Australia, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom as co-trustees of the Mandate of Nauru
Broome race riots
Edith Cowan, first female representative elected to an Australian parliament, Western Australia
First Archibald prize for portraiture is awarded to WB McInnes for Desbrowe Annear
Cyrill Callister of the Fred Walker Company develops vegemite, began selling in stores the following year
The Country Women's Association (CWA) is formed
Edward Hallstrom begins producing the first commercially available domestic refigerators using kerosene as a power source, followed by an electrically powered version in 1928
Grain Products Limited launched Weet-Bix, later acquired by Sanitarium in 1928
Introduction of compulsory voting at federal elections (not extending to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people)
MacRobertson Chocolates (later acquired by Cadbury) introduces the Cherry Ripe, Australia's oldest chocolate bar
The first car radio was fitted to an Australian car built by Kellys Motors in New South Wales
Australian Aboriginal Progressive Association formed
First circumnavigation flight around Australia by a seaplane by Ivor McIntyre and Stanley Goble
Eric Waterworth invents a record changer for playing several phonograph records in sequence without user intervention
Black Sunday bushfire in Victoria
Cactoblastis cactorum moths introduced as a biological control against prickly pear invasion
Alfred Traeger invents a pedal operated two-way radio
The Northern Territory is split at 20° south into Central Australia and North Australia
Parliament begins meeting in Canberra, moving the capital from Melbourne
The first commercial espresso machine arrives in Australia, installed in the Café Florentino, Burke Street Melbourne
First mention of a Dim Sim in the Melbourne Argus
Edgar H Booth and Mark C Liddell invent the electronic heart pacemaker
Reverend John Flynn creates the worlds first air ambulance, which would later be named the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS)
Bert Hinkler becomes the first person to fly solo from England to Australia
Charles Kingsford Smith lands in Brisbane completing flight over the Pacific, along with relief pilot Charles Ulm, and Americans; radio operator James Warner and navigator and engineer Harry Lyon
Donald Bradman's first international cricketing century
Charles Kingsford Smith and Charles Ulm make the first non-stop flight from Melbourne to Perth
Charles Kingsford Smith and Charles Ulm, along with navigator Harold Litchfield and radio operator Thomas McWilliams make the first flight from Australia to New Zealand
Hubert Wilkens makes the first flight over the Antarctic Continent
Global financial 'Great Depression' caused a massive shock to the Australian economy with 32% unemployed by 1932, with the impact felt from 1929 to 1939
Charlie Booth and his father invent the starting block used in track and field sprint events
Sydney's General Post Office (GPO) is the first site with a mechanised letter sorter
Frank Thring Sr of Efftee Studios in Melbourne invents the clapper board to synchronise sound and film
Amy Johnson becomes the first female to fly solo from England to Australia
Charles Kingsford Smith and Charles Ulm are the first to circumnavigate the earth by plane, from Oakland California to Oakland California, flying west
Phar Lap wins Melbourne Cup

Some 2,000 unemployed marched from Port Adelaide to the city protesting about beef being removed from unemployment rations, which descended into what is now known as the Beef Riot, with many hospitalised
Isaac Isaacs becomes the first Australian born governor-general
Central Australia and North Australia are merged back to become the Northern Territory again
First performance of the First Australian Ballet - Coppelia
Yorta Yorta elder William Cooper founds the Australian Aborigines' League
Chemist H. A. Milton Blake invents the first sunscreen
Opening of the Sydney Harbour Bridge
Formation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC)
England's 'Bodyline' Ashes cricket tour
Brahman cattle introduced to Australia
Designed by Lewis Bandt at Ford Australia in Geelong, the first coupé utility 'ute' rolls off the Ford production lines
Thomas Mayne at Nestlé develops the chocolate malt beverage Milo to improve nutrients in children's diets during the great depression
Minnie Crabb invents the Braille Printing Press, built to her specifications by H. Hulme
The illustrated Walkabout magazine begins publication in Australia
John and Sunday Reed purchase Heide in Melbourne, from which the Heide Circle emerged, and now the location of the Heide Museum of Modern Art
Justus Jorgensen establishes Montsalvat, an artists' community in Eltham, Melbourne
The Ashmore and Cartier Islands are transferred from the United Kingdom
Introduction of cane toads into Queensland
Art in Australia publishes Max Dupain's images informed by the functionalist aesthetic of the New Photography movement, signalling the beginning of modernist photography in Australia
United Kingdom transferred its Antarctica claim to Australia, becoming the Australian Antarctic Territory
The Tasmanian 'tiger' - the thylacine becomes extinct
The Hume Dam officially opened
Albert (Elea) Namatjira of the Western Arrernte people exhibits his first paintings, the style of which became associated with the Hermannsburg School of painting
William Ferguson and Jack Pattern launch the Aborigines Progressive Association
Edward Both invents the Both respirator or 'iron lung', a more affordable alternative to the more expensive machines available at the time
Max Dupain captures the iconic Sunbaker photo
Kodachrome 35mm roll film becomes available in Australia
Sesquicentenary celebrations of the landing of the first fleet, including a reanactment with coerced Aboriginal men from Menindee mission
Aboriginal Day of Mourning and Protest in response to the sesquicentenary, first national meeting of Aboriginal people for citizenship rights
Nora Heysen becomes the first woman to win the Archibald prize with her portrait Mme Elink Schuurman
The Contemporary Camera Groupe is formed by Max Dupain
The Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands is annexed to the Northern Territory. The Federal Capital Territory was renamed the Australian Capital Territory
Heat wave in Victoria followed by the Black Friday bushfires kills 438
Black Friday bushfires in Victoria
Prime Minister Menzies announces over the radio that 'Australia is at war', marking Australia's entry into World War II
Introduction of compulsory military service
Franklin George Barnes invents and patents a method of degaussing ships to reduce the threat of magnetic mines
The Angry Penguins art and literary journal is founded in Adelaide, later moving to Melbourne in 1942 and becoming the representation of the Angry Penguins Art Movement
Zinc cream sun block developed by Fauldings Pharmaceutical Company
Photographers Damien Parer, Australia's first combat cameraman, and Frank Hurley travel to Palestine with the Australian Imperial Force
First European war refugees arrive on the HMT Dunera
Soldiers riot in Brisbane against the 8pm closing time of pubs
Australia declares war on Japan following attack on Pearl Harbour, first declaration of war made independently of Britain
Japan invades Singapore, with 15,000 Australian soldiers captured, of which 7,000 would die as prisoners of war
Australian troops fighting in Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East return to fight in the Pacific
Prime Minister Curtin gives a radio address to Americans urging them to stand with Australia against the Japanese
The Mandate of Nauru is captured by Japan
Darwin bombed killing 243 people on the first day's attack, Japanese advance halted on Kokoda Trail
Montevideo Maru sunk by allied submarine, drowning more than 1,000 POWs and civilian internees, most of them Australian
William McArther invents the splayd, a combination of knife, fork, and spoon
Introduction of conscription
First women elected to the Australian Parliament, Dame Enid Lyons and Senator Dorothy Tangney
Formation of the Liberal Party of Australia
Lance Hill invents the Hills Hoist rotary clothes line (although the clothes line design was originally patented by Gilbert Toyne in Adelaide in 1926)
Australia plays a significant role in the founding of the United Nations advocating for smaller nations to have a vote, with the UN replacing the pre-war League of Nations
National introduction of sickness and unemployment benefits
Adopting a populate or perish policy, the Australian Government announces a post war immigration drive, softening the White Australia policy
The Japanese garrison in the Mandate of Nauru surrenders, a month after Japan announces its surrender
Florey, Fleming, and Chain win the Nobel Prize for developing penicillin
Agreement of Commonwealth and state governments to celebrate Australia Day on Jan 26
Polio epidemic, killing over 1,000 and crippling many more children for life. The epidemic went from 1946 until the vaccine was introduced in 1956
The Territory of New Guinea was reconstituted as a United Nations trust territory
The Mandate of Nauru was reconstituted as the United Nations Trust Territory of Nauru
Heard Island and McDonald Islands are transferred from the Unitied Kingdom to Australia
The Institute of Photographic Illustrators is formed in Sydney
The first locally made mass-production car launched, the Holden FX
Law enacted defining Australian citizenship, as up until this point Australians were deemed as British subjects
The Territory of New Guinea and Territory of Papua merged into the Territory of Papua and New Guinea
The Chifley Labor government begins the Snowy Mountains Hydo-Electric Scheme, an engineering project that continued to 1974
The Menzies Liberal government elected, the longest serving in Australian history for 23 years.
Korean War starts, ending in a stalemate and perpetual frozen conflict in 1953
Frank McEncroe creates the Chiko Roll
The CSIRO made CSIRAC computer plays the song 'Colonel Bogey March', the world's first instance of computer generated music
Eruption of Mount Lamington, Territory of Papua and New Guinea, killing 2,942
Conscription for the Korean war went from 1951 to 1959. Conscripted National Servicemen 'Nashos' did not end up serving overseas
Australia signs the ANZUS Treaty with New Zealand and the United States
The Malleys invent the Esky Auto Box, which lent the term 'Esky' to any portable cooler box
The Melbourne Argus is the first daily newspaper in the world to publish colour photographs
Victa begins production of Victa mowers, light motorised lawn mowers that became an icon of Australian suburbia
Sir Alan Walsh of the CSIRO develops the Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer
A CSIRO team led by Roger N Morse develop solar hot water
Bernard Yarnton Mills from the CSIRO invents and designs the Mills Cross Telescope, a two-dimensional radio telescope
Heard Island and McDonald Islands are formally declared the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands
First introduction of fluoride to an Australian town's drinking water in Beaconsfield, Tasmania
The first visit from a reigning monarch to Australia, Queen Elizabeth II
The Australian flag created shortly after Federation, becomes the national flag replacing the British Union Jack
Dr David Warren invents the black box flight recorder
Soviet spies, Vladimir and Evdokia Petrov masquerading as diplomats, defect to Australia
Australia's first Uranium mining commenced at the Rum Jungle mine in Northern Territory
Edward Bowen of the CSIRO invented and developed the Distance Measuring Equipment (DME) used to measure the distance between a plane and a ground station for navigation
Democratic Labor Party formed from a Labor Party split, partially stemming from fallout from the Petrov affair
Cocos (Keeling) Islands transferred by the United Kingdom from the Colony of Singapore to Australia, becoming the Territory of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands
Invention of the pneumatic broadacre air seeder
In a collaboration between Percy Begg of Adelaide and metallurgist Arthur Wilcock they create stainless steel braces tor gradual straightening of teeth
A portrait of Albert (Elea) Namatjira by William Dargie becomes the first of an Aboriginal person to win the Archibald Prize.
Introduction of the polio vaccine
Television broadcasts introduced in Australia
First nuclear weapons test by British at Maralinga
Melbourne hosts the Olympics, the first outside of Europe or the United States
Ian McWilliam invents the flame ionisation detector, still one of the most accurate instruments developed for the detection of emissions
Dr Arthur Farnworth of the CSIRO invents the SiroSet process for producing permanent creases in woolen fabrics
Albert (Elea) Namatjira becomes the first recorded Aboriginal person in the Northern Territory to be freed from the wards of the state restrictions, being granted full rights of citizenship
Christmas Island transferred by the United Kingdom from the Colony of Singapore to Australia, becoming the Territory of Christmas Island
ICI House (now Orica House) in Melbourne completed construction, the first modern skyscraper in Australia at 20 stories and 84 m in height
Jack Brabham becomes the first Australian to win a Formula One world championship, winning in a car of his own design
Eric Favelle creates the self constructing tower crane
Scientific Optical Laboratories of Adelaide produce the worlds first plastic spectacle lenses, reducing the weight of glass lenses by 60%
The federal government lifts ban on iron ore exports that had been in place since 1938
Introduction of the oral contraceptive pill
First Tupperware party in Australia
David Robinson and George Kossoff work at the Department of Health leads to the first commercially practical water bath medical ultrasound
The Australian Soccer Federation is established, later becoming the Australian Soccer Association then the Football Federation Australia
Aborignal and Torres Strait Islanders given the right to vote federally, regardless of State voting restrictions
Kodak makes the first instamatic cameras and colour Polaroids are introduced
Mervyn Bishop begins a cadetship at the Sydney Morning Herald, later becoming Australia's first Indigenous press photographer
Yirrkala bark petitions are presented to Australian Parliament's House of Representatives formally seeking to have the Yolngu people's land rights recognised
Australians fight under British command in a conflict between Indonesia and Malaysia on the island of Borneo, marking the last time Australia provides military assistance to a British conflict
Arnott's Biscuits Holdings begin selling Tim Tams
Jack Kennedy and Jim Lynch under commission from Raymond Lea Animation create the first animation rostrum
The Ansell company develops the first latex gloves
Menzies government introduces government aid for non-government schools
The National Service Act passed, introducing ballot based military conscription - 'Nashos' initially for the conflict in Borneo, then also for the war in Vietnam. The draft was between 1965 and 1972.
Jack Grant of Qantas invents the inflatable escape slide for aircraft
Thomas Angove of Renmark, South Australia invents the cardboard boxed wine cask
Menzies commits Australian troops to the Vietnam conflict
Switch to decimal currency
Immigration rules changed to no longer have a racial element, putting an end to the White Australia policy
Gurindji strike (Wave Hill Walk-Off)
The Easybeats becomes the first Australian band to have an international hit single with their 'Friday on My Mind'
Ronald Ryan becomes the last person to be executed in Australia
Black Tuesday bushfire in Tasmania

Indigenous referendum to change the constitution for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to be counted as part of the population and to be treated equally, allowing the Commonwealth to make laws on their behalf
CSIRO introduces dung beetles, having a significant impact on soil health and fly control
The Trust of Nauru becomes independent as the Republic of Nauru

Aboriginal boxer, Lionel Rose wins the World Bantamweight Championship, becomes the first Indigenous Australian to become Australian of the Year, and is appointed a Member of the Order of the British Empire

A court case in Victoria found that abortion was legally justified if it would otherwise place the woman at risk. This overthrew laws since the 19th century making abortions illegal under any circumstance
The first moon walk from the Apollo XI crew is televised to the world through the Honeysuckle Creek tracking station and Parkes radio telescope
The Coral Islands Territory created from Queensland
The first ATM installed in Sydney, however, the first computerised ATM was installed in 1977 in Brisbane
The 'Staysharp knife' was developed by Wiltshire
Anti-Vietnam war moratorium protests held, with the largest protest up to that time in Australia taking place in Melbourne
Germaine Greer's 'The Female Eunuch' is published
West Gate Bridge collapses during construction, killing 35 workers
Australia moved from the Imperial measurement system to metric
Arthur Bishop invents the variable rack and pinion steering for motor vehicles
The CSIRO develop the microwave landing system used by planes for assisted or 'blind landings'
The BLF impose the world's first green ban to protect a patch of bushland on Sydney's Lower North Shore
Neville Bonner of the Jagera people becomes the first Indigenous parliamentarian
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people counted in the census for the first time
Ted and Dorothy Wotherspoon become the first Aboriginal publicans in Australia in the New South Wales mining town of Catherine Hill Bay
The Territory of Papua and New Guinea renamed to Papua New Guinea
Aboriginal Tent Embassy established on Parliament House lawns in Canberra
Aboriginal artists from the settlement of Papunya begin painting traditional designs which was the beginning of the Western Desert art movement
Ralph Sarich of Perth invents the orbital internal combustion engine, now frequently used as an alternative to two-stroke engines.
Amdel Ltd develop equipment capable of instream analysis of metals during the recovery process reducing a 24 hour process to realtime.
Peter Talbot of Kambrook invents the power board, which Kambrook never patented
Gough Whitlam and the Labor Party voted back in after 23 years in opposition
Equal pay for both men and women legislated
Dr Bill Denholm and Dr John Floyd at the CSIRO and with Mount Isa Mines develop an energy efficient tin smelting process called the Sirosmelt lance and the ISA SMELT process
National Gallery of Australia buys Blue Poles by Jackson Pollock for $1.3 million, the most ever paid for an American painting up to that time
Patrick White wins the Nobel Prize in Literature for his body of written works
Sydney Opera House opens
The peninsula along Jervis Bay ceded to the ACT is formally named the Jervis Bay Territory
Gordon Withnall invents the Super Sopper for quickly soaking up water from sporting grounds to allow play to continue after rain
The Whitlam government abolishes university fees
"The Art of Aboriginal Australia" is the first major international exhibition of contemporary Australian Indigenous art, exhibited in Canada
Cyclone Tracy hits Darwin, resulting in 71 killed
The Aboriginal Islander Skills Development Scheme is founded. It later became the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association (NAISDA) in 1988
Tasman Bridge collapses after being struck by the ore carrier Lake Illawarra, 12 dead
Zip Industries design and patent the Instant Boiling Water Heater
South Australia is the first jurisdiction in Australia to decriminalise sex acts between men
The Family Law Act introduces 'no-fault' divorce
The health promotion campaign 'Life. Be in it' launches in Victoria
Colour TV introduced into Australia
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park created
The Republic of the North Solomons declared the independence of the region surrounding Bougainville Island in Papua New Guinea
Papua New Guinea becomes independent as the Independent State of Papua New Guinea rendering the dispute with the Republic of the North Solomons moot
Balibo, East Timor, 5 journalists murdered by Indonesian troops
The Governor-General John Kerr dismisses the Whitlam government and appoints Malcolm Fraser as the caretaker prime minister
The National Vision Research Institute of Australia develop the logMAR chart for testing vision acuity
By April 1975 Saigon had fallen to the North Vietnamese army. The first Vietnamese refugee boat arrives in Australia in April the following year
The Australian Government passes the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory Act), allowing for the return of Commonwealth lands to traditional owners
Granvill rail disaster with 83 dead and 213 injured
The Defence Science and Technology Organisation develop the Laser airborne depth sounder (LADS) used to calculate ocean depth from an aircraft
Japan launches a geostationary satellite to provide cloud-cover images of Australia to the Bureau of Meteorology
The last Australian whaling station in Albany closes
The Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) established
A team led by Dr Ted Ringwood of the Australian National University invents Synroc, a synthetic ceramic used to safely store radioactive waste in a crystalline structure

The first Sydney 'Mardi Gras' held as a celebration and a demonstration for gay rights and in commemoration of the US Stonewall riots, resulting in many arrests and names being published in the Sydney Morning Herald
The Ashmore and Cartier Islands are split from the Northern Territory, becoming the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands
Eastern Australian drought: 1979 - 1983
The Aboriginal Dance Theatre Redfern (ADTR) is founded by Christine Donnelly
The founders of Fairlight, Peter Vogel and Kim Ryrie invent the Digital Sampler, the first polyphonic digital sampling synthesizer
Geoff Healey with the Australian Television Network (now Seven Network) develops race cam for events such as motor racing
Professor Graeme Clark of the University of Melbourne invents the cochlear implant to provide sound to those with hearing loss
Baby Azaria Chamberlain disappears at Uluru
Bruce Thompson of Caroma in Australia develops the dual flush toilet
The Australian National University develop the Sensitive high mass-resolution ion microprobe (SHRIMP) for metallurgical assessment of rock samples
Phillip Hercus and Robert Clifford of Incat in Tasmania create the wave-piercing catamaran
Bill Jonas is the first Indigenous Australian to be awarded a PhD by the University of Papua New Guinea
The Defence Science and Technology Group develop the worlds first practical hovering rocket
Professor Colin Sullivan of Sydney University develop the Continuous Positive Airflow Pressure (CPAP) mask to treat sleep disordered breathing, which was commercialised in 1989 by ResMed
Publication of the Macquarie Dictionary
VFLs South Melbourne Football club moves to Sydney and becomes the Sydney Swans, the first interstate VFL team
The inaugural rugby league State of Origin series following origin matches in the previous two years
National Gallery of Australia in Canberra opens
Franklin Dam protests in Tasmania led to the formation of the Greens
Ash Wednesday bush fires in Victoria and South Australia
Australia II wins the America's Cup using a winged keel designed by Ben Lexcen, ending 132 years of the New York Yacht Clubs ownership of the event
The CSIRO develop the first vaccine against foot rot, commonly infecting sheep, goats, and cattle
Australian dollar floated
Introduction of Medicare
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people gained full elector equality with enrolling to vote made compulsory at federal elections for Indigenous Australians
The world's first frozen embryo baby is born in Melbourne
The baby safety capsule is invented for transporting new borns in cars
The Audio-Tactile Pedestrian Detector (PB/5 ATPD) developed for safe pedestrian road crossings
Sex Discrimination Act passed in the Australian Parliament
Dr Richard Fawdry and Dr Bill Burch invents Technegas, an inhalable radioactively tagged aerosol, used for imaging of lung ventilation
Dr Robert Clancy of University of Newcastle develops the bronchitis vaccine, reducing attacks of acute bronchitis by up to 90%
Australian Government returns Uluru to its traditional owners
NADOC '86 Exhibition of Aboriginal and Islander Photographers, the first exhibition by Indigeneous photographers, shown at the Aboriginal Artists Gallery, Sydney
CSIRO scientists, Wayne Gerlach and Jim Haseloff discover gene shears, genetic material that can be used to cut out genes from DNA
The Australia Act 1986 makes Australia completely independent of the United Kingdom
Russell St bombing, Melbourne
Hoddle St massacre, Melbourne
Queen St massacre, Melbourne
Boomalli Aboriginal Artists Co-operative Gallery established by Brenda L Croft, Tracey Moffat, and Michael Riley to promote urban Aboriginal art
The Bicentenary of the arrival of the First Fleet is celebrated in Australia
The Bicentenary of the arrival of the First Fleet generates massive protests and the largest ever demonstrations for land rights
CSIRO scientists led by Dr David Solomon develop the polymer bank note
The University of Adelaide invent the first non-chemical biological pesticide
Bangarra Dance Theatre is founded
Jervis Bay Territory split from the ACT to become its own territory
Hawke government introduces HECS fees for higher education

Ron Warrender and Milutin Stoilovic at the Australian National University develop Unilite, a forensic tool for seeing fingerprints, scribbled over writing, or reworked paintings. Rofin Australia Pty Ltd have developed this into the portable Polilight
Earthquake hits Newcastle
Following the international stock market crashes starting from Oct, 1987, Australia went into "The recession we had to have" with a number of financial institutions collapsing
The VFL gets renamed to the AFL, reflecting its national composition

Millenium drought spanning from 1991 to 2010, regarded as the worst drought recorded since European colonisation, commencing in Queensland in 1991 before spreading to the southern states in the following years
The CSIRO develop the buffalo fly trap for removing the flys from cows
Dr Michael Ryan and Dr Stephen Ruff at Sydney's North Shore Hospital develop the plastic rod bone repair technique, replacing metal pins and screws which interfere with MRI and CAT scans
Dr Victor Chang at St Vincent's Hospital, Sydney develops the St Vincents heart valve for the replacement of dysfunctional ventricle heart valves
Port Hedland immigration detention centre opens
Stephen Newman from Queensland invents the world's first mult-focal contact lens
Dr Fiona Wood at Royal Perth Hospital develops spray-on skin for treatment of damaged skin such as from burns or abrasions
Ric Richardson patents software product activation to allow the digital distribution of his own software
Mabo native title case recognised in High Court decision
The first Indigenous owned restaurant in Victoria (and possibly Australia) opens in Halls Gap - the Branbuk Koori Restaurant or Gugidjela
AFL player Nick Winmar responds to racist abuse from spectators
The Native Title Act is passed, intended to provide a national system for the recognition and protection of native title
Australian dogs withdrawn from Antarctica, having been used there since the 1950s
Bruce Macdonald at the Australian Institute of Marine Science develops the first underwater computer which included a five-button handheld keypad
Jim Frazier designs the Frazier lens which provides a very large depth of field, allowing both the foreground and background to be in focus
Asynchronous Transfer Method (ATM) was the first network protocol to simultaneously support telephony (voice), data, and video signals on the one network
The ACT bans smoking in restaurants, the first state or territory government in Australia to introduce a smoking ban
The CSIRO develop the EXELGRAM - an optical counterfeiting technology
A CSIRO team led by Dr Peter Waterhouse discover double-stranded RNA trigger gene silencing
CSIRO develop the Jindalee Radar System which detects stealth aircraft from the air turbulence that they generate
Northern Territory passes a Voluntary Assisted Dying law which was nullified by the Federal Government two years later
CSIRO patents the technology used by Wi-Fi, although the Wi-Fi trademark is owned by a US based consortium
A team at Monash University in Melbourne led by Mark von Itzstein develop Relenza, and anti-flu medication
National Firearms Agreement follows Port Arthur massacre, where 35 were killed
Nova Peris at the Atlanta Olympics becomes the first Indigenous Australian to win an Olympic gold medel
Elizabeth Reef and Middleton Reef transferred from New South Wales to the Coral Sea Island Territory
Thredbo landslide, kills 18
George Briscoe becomes the first Indigenous Australian to be awarded a PhD from an Australian University (ANU)
Australia votes 'No' in a referendum on whether Australia should become a republic
Walk for Reconcilliation across Sydney Harbour Bridge
Cathy Freeman lights the Olympic flame at the Sydney Olympics and wins the 400 m gold medal
Australian troops take control of the Norwegian Tampa cargo vessel carrying rescued asylum-seekers, refusing it entry into Australian waters
ACT becomes the first jurisdiction in Australia to decriminalise abortions
Steven Bradbury wins Olympic gold in the 1,000m speed skating event, coming from last position. The first Australian Winter Olympic gold medal
Glenn Murcutt wins the Pritzker Architecture Prize
Bali bombings kill 202 people including 88 Australians
Canberra firestorm destroys 510 properties and the deaths of four people
Peter Stephinson invents Blast Glass, which proved effective in protecting the Australian Embassy in the Jakarta bombings of 2004
The CSIRO develop the UltraBattery, a hybrid technology combining a traditional lead-acid battery with a supercapacitor
Kodak Australia closes its manufacturing plant in Melbourne
Redfern riots following the death of a 17 year old Aboriginal teenager who was being chased by the police
US free trade agreement signed
Cronulla race riots
Professor Ian Frazer from University of Queensland creates a vaccine for preventing cervical cancer. The commercial vaccine, Gardasil provides protection against certain types of HPV
The Gallery of Modern Art (GOMA) in Brisbane opens
Murray-Darling Basin Agreement (Water Act) starts
Global Financial Crises - global recession between 2008 - 2009. Australia fares better than most countries.
Australian cities are photographically recorded and added to Google Street View
National Apology to the Stolen Generations
Heat wave in South-eastern Australia kills 374 people and triggers the Black Saturday bushfires
Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria result in the deaths of 173 people
National Apology to Forgotten Australians and former child migrants
Flu pandemic, with death toll possibly as high as 1,600
Ken Wyatt becomes the first Indigenous member of the House of Representatives
Julia Gillard becomes the first female prime minister
A team at the University of Queensland develop Robotic Visual Horizon, allowing autonomous unmanned flight modelled on how bee's brains process visual information when flying

The Museum of Old and New Art (MONA) owned by David Walsh opens in Hobart, replacing its precursor, the Moorilla Museum of Antiquities which ran from 2001 to 2006. MONA is also strongly associated with the MOFO festival
National ICT Australia and Open Kernel Labs release seL4 microkernel, a small operating system kernel that distinguishes between trusted and untrusted software, resistent to hacking
Hurricane Yasi destroys Queensland's banana crop
CSIRO produce the first vaccine to protect horses from the Hendra virus
Researchers from the University of New South Wales build the first quantum bit
Fourth inquest into Azaria Chamberlain's death finds that she died from being attacked or taken by a dingo
Mercy Health identify a blood test that can help prevent stillbirths
Bureau of Meteorology adds a new colour to take the temperature scale up to 54°C
Nova Peris becomes Australia's first Indigenous woman elected to federal parliament
National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) introduced
High Court of Australia recognises non-specific sex identification
Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 disappears, possibly over the Indian Ocean
Russian militants shoot down Malaysian Airlines Flight MH17 over Ukraine
Engineers at the University of New South Wales build the first quantum logic gate
Melbourne thunderstorm results in approx 8,500 hospital admissions for asthma and related respiratory symptoms
Sydney Lindt Café siege
Car used to run down people in Bourke St, Melbourne
Uluru Statement from the Heart
First game in the AFL Women's competition
The Darlington Statement on intersex rights is agreed to
Victoria becomes the first State to pass a Voluntary Assisted Dying (euthenasia) law, after the Federal Government overrode the Northern Territory's law of 1995.
Same sex marriage becomes legal in Australia
International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) wins Nobel Peace Prize
Car used to ram people corner of Flinders St and Eliizabeth St, Melbourne
Govt of Victoria, RMIT University, and Swinburne University with Professor Blamey and Professor Elaine Saunders release the first modular hearing aid
Timber Creek case determines the approach for resolving native title compensation claims
AFL provides an apology to Adam Goodes
Black Summer bushfires kills nearly 500 people, between 2019 and 2020
The first case of COVID-19 is confirmed in Australia
